title: Parallel Clique Counting and Peeling Algorithms

sections.introduction:
Finding kğ‘˜k-cliques in a graph is a fundamental
graph-theoretic problem with a long history of study both in theory
and practice. In recent years, kğ‘˜k-clique counting and listing have
been widely applied in practice due to their many applications,
including in learning network embeddingsÂ ,
understanding the structure and formation of
networksÂ  , identifying dense subgraphs for
community detectionÂ  8  , and
graph partitioning and compressionÂ . For sparse graphs, the best known sequential algorithm is by Chiba and
NishizekiÂ , and requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work
(number of operations), where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the arboricity of the
graph.111A graph has arboricity Î±ğ›¼\alpha if the minimum number of spanning forests needed to cover the graph is Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The state-of-the-art clique parallel kğ‘˜k-clique counting algorithm is
kClistÂ , which achieves the same work bound,
but does not have a strong theoretical bound on the
span (parallel time). Furthermore, kClist as well as existing parallel kğ‘˜k-clique counting
algorithms have limited scalability for graphs with more than a few
hundred million edges, but real-world graphs today frequently contain
billions to hundreds of billions of edgesÂ [ref]34. kğ‘˜k-clique Counting.
In this paper, we design a new parallel kğ‘˜k-clique counting algorithm,
arb-count that matches the work of Chiba-Nishezeki, has
polylogarithmic span, and has improved space complexity compared to
kClist. Our algorithm is able to significantly outperform kClist and
other competitors, and scale to larger graphs than prior work.
arb-count is based on using low out-degree orientations of the graph
to reduce the total work.
Assuming that we have a low out-degree ranking of the graph, we show
that for a constant kğ‘˜k we can count or list all kğ‘˜k-cliques in
Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work, and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n+log2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›O(k\log n+\log^{2}n) span with high probability (whp),222We say Oâ€‹(fâ€‹(n))ğ‘‚ğ‘“ğ‘›O(f(n)) with
high probability (whp) to indicate Oâ€‹(câ€‹fâ€‹(n))ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘›O(cf(n)) with probability
at least 1âˆ’nâˆ’c1superscriptğ‘›ğ‘1-n^{-c} for câ‰¥1ğ‘1c\geq 1, where nğ‘›n is the input size.
where mğ‘šm is the number of edges in the graph and Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the
arboricity of the graph. Having work bounds parameterized by Î±ğ›¼\alpha is
desirable since most real-world graphs have low
arboricityÂ [ref]17. Theoretically, arb-count requires
Oâ€‹(Î±)ğ‘‚ğ›¼O(\alpha) extra space per processor; in contrast, the kClist algorithm requires Oâ€‹(Î±2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ›¼2O(\alpha^{2}) extra space per processor. Furthermore, kClist does not achieve polylogarithmic span. We also design an approximate kğ‘˜k-clique counting algorithm
based on counting on a sparsified graph. We show in the appendix that our approximate algorithm
produces unbiased estimates and runs in Oâ€‹(pâ€‹mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2+m)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2ğ‘šO(pm\alpha^{k-2}+m)
work and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n+log2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›O(k\log n+\log^{2}n) span whp for a sampling
probability of pğ‘p. Parallel Ranking Algorithms.
We present two new parallel algorithms
for efficiently ranking the vertices, which we use for kğ‘˜k-clique counting. We show that a distributed
algorithm by Barenboim and ElkinÂ  can be implemented
in linear work and polylogarithmic span. We also parallelize an
external-memory algorithm by Goodrich and PszonaÂ  and
obtain the same complexity bounds.
We believe that our parallel ranking algorithms may be of
independent interest, as many other subgraph finding algorithms use
low out-degree orderings
(e.g.,Â   ). Peeling and kğ‘˜k-Clique Densest Subgraph.
We also present new parallel algorithms for the
kğ‘˜k-clique densest subgraph problem, a generalization of the densest subgraph problem
that was first introduced by TsourakakisÂ . This
problem admits a natural 1/k1ğ‘˜1/k-approximation by peeling vertices in
order of their incident kğ‘˜k-clique counts. We present a parallel peeling
algorithm, arb-peel, that peels all vertices with the
lowest kğ‘˜k-clique count on each round and uses arb-count as a subroutine.
The expected amortized work of arb-peel is Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2+Ïkâ€‹(G)â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğºğ‘›O(m\alpha^{k-2}+\rho_{k}(G)\log n) and
the span is Oâ€‹(Ïkâ€‹(G)â€‹kâ€‹logâ¡n+log2â¡n)ğ‘‚subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğºğ‘˜ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›O(\rho_{k}(G)k\log n+\log^{2}n) whp, where Ïkâ€‹(G)subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğº\rho_{k}(G) is the
number of rounds needed to completely peel the graph.
We also prove in the appendix that the problem of obtaining the hierarchy given by
this process is ğ–¯ğ–¯\mathsf{P}-complete for k>2ğ‘˜2k>2, indicating that a polylogarithmic-span
solution is unlikely. Tsourakakis also shows that naturally extending the Bahmani et
al.Â  algorithm for approximate densest subgraph gives
an 1/(kâ€‹(1+Ïµ))1ğ‘˜1italic-Ïµ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation in Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) parallel
rounds, although they were not concerned about work.
We present
an Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work and polylogarithmic-span algorithm,
arb-approx-peel, for obtaining a 1/(kâ€‹(1+Ïµ))1ğ‘˜1italic-Ïµ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation to
the kğ‘˜k-clique densest subgraph problem. We obtain this work bound using our kğ‘˜k-clique algorithm as a subroutine.
Danisch et al.Â  use their kğ‘˜k-clique counting
algorithm as a subroutine to implement these two approximation
algorithms for kğ‘˜k-clique densest subgraph, but their implementations do not have
provably-efficient bounds. Experimental Evaluation.
We present implementations of our algorithms that use various
optimizations to achieve good practical performance. We
perform a thorough experimental study on a 30-core
machine with two-way hyper-threading and compare to prior work.
We show that on a variety of real-world graphs and different
kğ‘˜k, our kğ‘˜k-clique counting algorithm achieves 1.31â€“9.88x speedup over the
state-of-the-art parallel kClist algorithmÂ  and
self-relative speedups of 13.23â€“38.99x.
We also compared our kğ‘˜k-clique counting algorithm to other
parallel kğ‘˜k-clique counting implementations including Jain and Seshadhriâ€™s
Pivoter , Mhedhbi and Salihogluâ€™s worst-case optimal
join algorithm (WCO) , Lai et al.â€™s
implementation of a binary join algorithm (BinaryJoin)
, and Pinar et al.â€™s ESCAPE
, and demonstrate speedups of up to several orders of
magnitude. Furthermore, by integrating state-of-the-art parallel graph
compression techniques, we can process graphs
with tens to hundreds of billions of edges, significantly
improving on the capabilities of existing implementations. As
far as we know, we are the first to report 444-clique counts for
Hyperlink2012, the largest publicly-available graph, with over
two hundred billion undirected edges. We study the accuracy-time tradeoff of our sampling algorithm, and
show that is able to approximate the clique counts with 5.05% error
5.32â€“6573.63 times more quickly than running our exact counting
algorithm on the same graph. We compare our sampling algorithm to
Bressan et al.â€™s serial MOTIVO ,
and demonstrate 92.71â€“177.29x speedups. Finally, we study our two
parallel approximation algorithms for kğ‘˜k-clique densest subgraph and show that our we are
able to outperform kClist by up to 29.59x and achieve 1.19â€“13.76x
self-relative speedup. We demonstrate up to 53.53x speedup over Fang
et al.â€™s serial CoreApp  as well. The contributions of this paper are as follows: A parallel algorithm with Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) and polylogarithmic
span whp for kğ‘˜k-clique counting. Parallel algorithms for low out-degree
orientations with Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) work and Oâ€‹(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n) span whp. An Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) amortized expected work parallel algorithm for
computing a 1/k1ğ‘˜1/k-approximation to the kğ‘˜k-clique densest subgraph problem, and an Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Î±kâˆ’2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work and polylogarithmic-span whp
algorithm for computing a 1/(kâ€‹(1+Ïµ))1ğ‘˜1italic-Ïµ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation. Optimized implementations of our algorithms that achieve
significant speedups over existing state-of-the-art methods, and
scale to the largest publicly-available graphs. Our code is publicly available at: https://github.com/ParAlg/gbbs/tree/master/benchmarks/CliqueCounting.
